entries.title: Peter Conroy, former leader of the Shannon Rovers Irish Pipe Band, dies at 90
entries.summary:
On the sizeable list of things Pete Conroy did in his life that might prompt one to say "Wait, back up, you did what?" he'd probably put heading up the Shannon Rovers Irish Pipe Band at the top.

That is, if you got him talking at all. He was a humble man of few words.

For years, when the group played "Amazing Grace" at venues ranging from parades to funerals and weddings, it was Mr. Conroy's bagpipe solo that began the powerful tune before his bandmates joined.

As the pipe major, or leader of the group, Mr. Conroy is credited with lifting standards of practice and play, driving the group to release an album, and helping it compete and win bagpipe competitions.

Mr. Conroy died Jan. 20 from natural causes. He was 90.

He was a member of the group for about 26 years before hand tremors forced him to give it up around the year 2002.

A few months before he died, Mr. Conroy's namesake son, Peter, reached out to the Shannon Rovers to see if a couple bagpipers might be able to come to the west suburban memory care facility where his father lived to help celebrate his birthday.

"The day came and I'm looking out the window of the recreation room with my dad and I couldn't believe it. There had to be 20 bagpipers and drummers and the color guard that all came," said Mr. Conroy's son.

"I invited other staff and patients at the facility to listen. And then they performed. And it was loud. And it was big. And I looked at my dad, who'd been in a wheelchair for the last year or so, and his fingers were moving as if he was playing the pipes. And dad was there in his glory, he understood the moment."

The pipes were his passion, a proud nod to his Celtic roots, but no day job, his family said.

Mr. Conroy was a geological engineer who helped design dams and reservoirs in places around the globe.

His travels filled up 25 passports — including a few Irish ones he used when flying to countries that might not have the warmest view of Americans.

His parents were first generation Irish Americans, which allowed him dual citizenship, and Mr. Conroy could easily slide in and out of an Irish brogue.

Upon return to the family's home in Elmhurst, his kids would mob him and wait with anxious joy to see what exotic trinkets he'd brought home for them. Items included Icelandic sweaters, a glass-encased tarantula and a blow gun.

His son, Peter, the recipient of the blow gun, recalled his father saying: "I had the option to get the dipped-in-poison darts, or just the plain ones — you got the plain ones."

He also once brought a parakeet home from overseas. It was a squawky pet for a time. Then it flew away.

Mr. Conroy was born July 30, 1935, in Chicago to Winifred and Peter Conroy. He was a Chicago cop. She ran the boarding house where the family lived in Garfield Park.

Mr. Conroy attended St. Mel High School and St. Joseph's College in Indiana.

In his 30s, married with three kids, he went back to school to earn a Ph.D. He took a three-week road trip to visit the schools he was interested in, camping in state and national parks along with his family.

He chose Missouri University of Science and Technology in Rolla and drove there in a U-Haul with his wife, kids and the family dog, which drank from a sloshing fish bowl that somehow still contained several guppies upon arrival.

While in Missouri, Mr. Conroy found time to buy an old Model A Ford for $400 from a Missouri farmer and restore it.

"I drove it to high school in the '70s, and I'd give it an ahooga as I pulled in," said his son, imitating the sound of its horn. "I looked like Eliot Ness."

After he earned his master's degree and moved back to Elmhurst, Mr. Conroy bought a Cessna airplane, joined a flying club and in 1999 he flew from Illinois to Alaska with a neighbor who was a United Airlines pilot.

He also learned to scuba dive, made wine in his kitchen and built a grandfather clock.

Mr. Conroy's wife, Jeanine Conroy, died in 2020. They'd been married for 63 years. She grew up across the street from Mr. Conroy.

He first saw the Shannon Rovers play at a wedding and became enamored. One of their members, Barney McCudden, a Scotsman with a thick accent, taught Mr. Conroy how to play.

Years later Mr. Conroy himself taught many future Shannon Rovers how to play the bagpipes.

"He's one of the reasons the Shannon Rovers are celebrating our 100th anniversary this year," said Brian Costello, the group's current pipe major.

The group leads the city's downtown St. Patrick's Day Parade before dispersing to perform at bars and events throughout the city.

"While making the rounds one year at Irish pubs, a drunk lady lifted his kilt because, well, you know that old joke about 'What's under the kilt?' But I was like 'That's my father!' I was ready to take her down," recalled his daughter Anne Margaret Peachey, with a laugh.

In addition to his son and daughter, Mr. Conroy is survived by another daughter, Mary Showers, as well as seven grandchildren and 14 great grandchildren.

Services have been held.

entries.title: What to know about Illinois' 7th Congressional District Democratic primary
entries.summary: <p>Richard Boykin, Kina Collins, Melissa Conyears-Ervin, Anthony Driver, David Ehrlich, Thomas Fisher, La Shawn Ford, Jason Friedman, Rory Hoskins, Anabel Mendoza, Jazmin Robinson, Reed Showalter and Felix Tello are running for the Democratic nomination to replace <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/07/30/danny-davis-wont-seek-reelection-congress" >retiring U.S. Rep. Danny Davis</a> in the 7th Congressional District, which stretches from the South Side to the western suburbs.</p><p></p><h3>So what? </h3><p>Davis has held the seat for nearly three decades, and the primary winner in this heavily Democratic district will be favored to replace the retiring congressman. They’ll face the winner of the Republican primary that includes Chad Koppie and Patricia “P Rae” Easley.</p><h3>What does a U.S. representative do? </h3><p>Representatives vote on federal laws, advocate for their districts and work to secure federal funding and other resources for constituents.</p><h3>Why is U.S. representative a powerful position? </h3><p>Members of Congress vote on laws that affect all Americans.</p><h3><b>Who are the candidates?</b></h3><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-92ae8742-fd39-11f0-a56e-bf18f95939f2"><li><b>Richard Boykin</b> is an attorney, former Cook County commissioner and former chief of staff to Davis. Boykin has also run unsuccessful campaigns for county board president and circuit court clerk.</li><li><b>Kina Collins </b>is a community organizer and anti-gun violence activist who is making her fourth run for the seat.</li><li><b>Melissa Conyears-Ervin </b>is a former state representative serving her second term as Chicago’s city treasurer. She finished as runner-up to Davis in the 2024 Democratic primary.</li><li><b>Anthony Driver </b>is executive director of the Service Employees International Union Illinois State Council, an influential labor union. He was the first president of the Community Commission for Public Safety and Accountability, where he remains a commissioner.</li><li><b>David Ehrlich </b>is an adjunct lecturer at UIC’s College of Urban Planning and Public Affairs who previously worked as a senior analyst for the U.S. Government Accountability Office.</li><li><b>Thomas Fisher</b> is an emergency physician at the University of Chicago Medical Center who served as a White House Fellow under the Obama administration during the rollout of the Affordable Care Act.</li><li><b>La Shawn Ford</b> has served as a West Side state representative since 2007. He has been endorsed by Davis, and he ran for mayor in 2019.</li><li><b>Jason Friedman </b>is an owner and former president of Friedman Properties, a massive River North real estate firm with deep ties to several mayoral administrations. He once worked under Rahm Emanuel in former President Bill Clinton’s administration.</li><li><b>Rory Hoskins </b>is the first Black mayor of Forest Park, serving his second term after two terms as a commissioner in the west suburb.</li><li><b>Anabel Mendoza</b> is an immigrant rights organizer with the youth-led nonprofit United We Dream. At 27, she’s the youngest candidate in the race.</li><li><b>Jazmin Robinson</b> is a corporate human resources worker and improv performer calling for an end to big-money influence in politics.</li><li><b>Reed Showalter </b>is a former Federal Trade Commission attorney, U.S. Justice Department counsel and White House National Economic Council adviser who stepped down after President Donald Trump returned to office.</li><li><b>Felix Tello </b>is a technology engineer who says he’d deploy an app for constituents to weigh in on how he’d cast votes in Congress.</li></ul><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-aa0000" name="module-aa0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Illinois 2026 primary election schedule</h3><br><b>Feb. 5</b>: Early voting and vote by mail begins<br><br><b>March 1</b>: Online voter registration ends, but voters may register in person at <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/VotingAndRegistrationSystems/EarlyVotingLocationsSearch.aspx" target="_blank" >election authority and early voting sites</a><br><br><b>March 12</b>: Deadline for online and posted applications to vote by mail; in-person requests for absentee ballots may be made through March 16<br><br><b>March 17</b>: Polls open for Primary Election Day from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.<br><br><b>March 31</b>: Deadline to return absentee ballots postmarked on or before Primary Election Day</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: What to know about Illinois' 8th Congressional District Democratic primary
entries.summary: <p>Junaid Ahmed, Yasmeen Bankole, Melissa Bean, Sanjyot Dunung, Neil Khot, Kevin Morrison, Dan Tully and Ryan Vetticad are running for the Democratic nomination to replace U.S. Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi in the 8th Congressional District, which is anchored in the northwest suburbs.</p><p></p><h3>So what? </h3><p>Krishnamoorthi is giving up the congressional seat he’s held for nearly a decade to seek retiring U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin’s seat. The winner of the Democratic primary will be favored in November’s general election over the winner of the Republican field, which includes Kevin Ake, Jennifer Davis, Herbert Hebein and Mark Rice.</p><h3>What does a U.S. representative do? </h3><p>Representatives vote on federal laws, advocate for their districts and work to secure federal funding and other resources for constituents.</p><h3>Why is U.S. representative a powerful position? </h3><p>Members of Congress vote on laws that affect all Americans.</p><h3>Who are the candidates?</h3><p><b>Junaid Ahmed </b>is a tech entrepreneur who unsuccessfully challenged Krishnamoorthi in the 2022 primary.</p><p><b>Yasmeen Bankole</b> is a Hanover Park village trustee who has worked for both Krishnamoorthi and U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin.</p><p><b>Melissa Bean</b> is aiming to take back the seat she held for three terms before losing it to conservative Joe Walsh about 15 years ago.</p><p><b>Sanjyot Dunung</b> runs a global education company and served on a foreign working group under former President Joe Biden.</p><p><b>Neil Khot</b> is a tech services business owner and first-generation Indian immigrant.</p><p><b>Kevin Morrison</b> is a two-term Cook County commissioner and the first openly gay member of the board.</p><p><b>Dan Tully</b> is a former judge advocate in the U.S. Army Reserve and foreign assistance worker for the Department of Commerce who left federal service in protest of Trump administration policies.</p><p><b>Ryan Vetticad</b> worked as a Justice Department data analyst assisting in investigations of the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection at the U.S. Capitol who resigned in protest when Donald Trump retook the White House.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-860000" name="module-860000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Illinois 2026 primary election schedule</h3><br><b>Feb. 5</b>: Early voting and vote by mail begins<br><br><b>March 1</b>: Online voter registration ends, but voters may register in person at <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/VotingAndRegistrationSystems/EarlyVotingLocationsSearch.aspx" target="_blank" >election authority and early voting sites</a><br><br><b>March 12</b>: Deadline for online and posted applications to vote by mail; in-person requests for absentee ballots may be made through March 16<br><br><b>March 17</b>: Polls open for Primary Election Day from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.<br><br><b>March 31</b>: Deadline to return absentee ballots postmarked on or before Primary Election Day</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: What to know about state legislative races in Illinois' March 17 primary
entries.summary: <p>A slew of candidates are facing off in the March 17 primary for Illinois General Assembly seats. Here's a brief look at what's at stake.</p><h3>What is the General Assembly?</h3><h3></h3><p>The Illinois General Assembly meets at the state Capitol in Springfield every January to debate and vote on proposed laws, adjourning in May or June. There are 118 members of the Illinois House of Representatives and 59 members of the Illinois Senate. </p><p>Democrats make up 78 of the seats in the Illinois House, giving them a strong majority. All state representatives serve two-year terms with elections on even-numbered years, meaning all the seats are up for a vote in 2026.</p><p>Illinois Senate races, on the other hand, are staggered. There are 39 seats up for election this year. As is the case in the House, Democrats have a supermajority in the Senate, controlling 40 seats to Republicans 29.</p><p>To locate your state Senate and House districts and learn who is representing you in Springfield, go <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/electionoperations/districtlocator/districtofficialsearchbyaddress.aspx" target="_blank" >here</a> on the Illinois State Board of Elections website.</p><h3>What are a few key races? </h3><p>Some incumbents jumped to run for congressional seats or other offices, opening contests across the city.</p><p>After winning election in 2006, La Shawn Ford has been representing the 8th House district ever since. But he is vying for U.S. Rep. Danny Davis’ congressional seat, and that leaves Jill Bush, Shantel Franklin, John Harrell and Latonya Mitts competing to succeed him on the West Side and western suburban post.</p><p>After two terms in the Illinois House, Hoan Huynh jumped into the race to succeed Rep. Jan Schakowsky in Congress, leaving a wide-open race in the 13th district on the North Side. Five candidates are vying to replace Huynh, including Adam Braun, Ridge Knapp, Sunjay Kumar, James O’Brien and Demi Palecek.</p><p>In the 9th Senate district, Patrick Hanley and Rachel Ruttenberg are competing to succeed state Sen. Laura Fine, who also is running in a crowded field of candidates to replace Schakowsky. The district dips into the North Side but mostly represents North Shores suburbs.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-4a0000" name="module-4a0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Illinois 2026 primary election schedule</h3><br><b>Feb. 5</b>: Early voting and vote by mail begins<br><br><b>March 1</b>: Online voter registration ends, but voters may register in person at <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/VotingAndRegistrationSystems/EarlyVotingLocationsSearch.aspx" target="_blank" >election authority and early voting sites</a><br><br><b>March 12</b>: Deadline for online and posted applications to vote by mail; in-person requests for absentee ballots may be made through March 16<br><br><b>March 17</b>: Polls open for Primary Election Day from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.<br><br><b>March 31</b>: Deadline to return absentee ballots postmarked on or before Primary Election Day</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: What to know about the Illinois Republican primary race for governor
entries.summary: <p>Darren Bailey, Ted Dabrowski, Rick Heidner and James Mendrick are running for <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2025/11/03/rick-heidner-illinois-candidate-filing-governor" target="_blank" ><u>the Republican nomination for governor</u></a> to advance to a general election matchup with Gov. JB Pritzker, who is unopposed in the Democratic primary.</p><p></p><h3>So what? </h3><p>The Republican nominee will aim to prevent a third term for Pritzker, who is widely considered to have presidential ambitions in 2028. Republicans have been shut out of all statewide offices in Illinois since Pritzker unseated former Gov. Bruce Rauner in 2018.</p><h3>What does a governor do? </h3><p>The governor is the state’s chief executive, signing state bills into law, overseeing numerous state agencies and advocating for the state on the national stage.</p><h3>Why is governor a powerful position?</h3><p>The governor helps set the legislative agenda for the Illinois General Assembly, proposes state budgets, appoints leaders of state agencies and advocates for federal resources.</p><h3>Who are the candidates?</h3><p><b>Darren Bailey</b>, a farmer and former state legislator from Xenia in southern Illinois, won the 2022 GOP nomination for governor <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2022/6/28/23187510/darren-bailey-richard-irvin-pritzker-republican-governors-race-jesse-sullivan" >in a landslide</a> before losing to Pritzker by nearly 13 percentage points <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2022/11/8/23448412/j-b-pritzker-declares-victory-over-gop-challenger-darren-bailey" >in the general election</a>. After a failed bid for Congress, Bailey's looking to run it back against Pritzker, this time with lieutenant governor candidate <b>Aaron Del Mar</b>, the Cook County Republican Party chair who joined the ticket in an effort to court moderate suburban voters.</p><p><b>Ted Dabrowski </b>is the former president of the conservative research and commentary website Wirepoints and a former leader and spokesman of the conservative Illinois Policy Institute. The Wilmette resident’s running mate is <b>Carrie Mendoza</b>, an emergency physician.</p><p><b>Rick Heidner</b> is a video gambling mogul, real estate entrepreneur and frequent political donor to both sides of the aisle. His businesses sometimes have had contentious relationships with state regulators under the Pritzker administration. Heidner's running mate is <b>Christina Neitzke-Troike</b>, mayor of southwest suburban Homer Glen.<b> </b></p><p><b>James Mendrick </b>is the two-term sheriff of DuPage County. His running mate is author and Army veteran <b>Robert Renteria</b>.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-7d0000" name="module-7d0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Illinois 2026 primary election schedule</h3><br><b>Feb. 5</b>: Early voting and vote by mail begins<br><br><b>March 1</b>: Online voter registration ends, but voters may register in person at <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/VotingAndRegistrationSystems/EarlyVotingLocationsSearch.aspx" target="_blank" >election authority and early voting sites</a><br><br><b>March 12</b>: Deadline for online and posted applications to vote by mail; in-person requests for absentee ballots may be made through March 16<br><br><b>March 17</b>: Polls open for Primary Election Day from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.<br><br><b>March 31</b>: Deadline to return absentee ballots postmarked on or before Primary Election Day</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: What to know about the March 17 primary for Illinois comptroller
entries.summary: <p>Margaret Croke, Stephanie Kifowit, Holly Kim and Karina Villa are the Democrats vying to replace outgoing incumbent Susana Mendoza as the state comptroller.</p><h3><b>What does the Illinois comptroller do?</b></h3><p>The Illinois comptroller is the state’s chief financial officer. The office manages the state’s fiscal accounts, records all transactions, pays bills and reviews all expenditures and contracts. The comptroller also chairs the State Employees’ Retirement System Board and sits on the Illinois State Board of Investment, helping manage pensions for state employees. The comptroller also issues financial reports about the state’s fiscal affairs. In addition to managing the state’s finances, the office regulates cemeteries and handles the fiduciary protection of cemetery funds meant for the maintenance of grave sites in Illinois.</p><h3><b>Who is the current comptroller?</b></h3><p>Susana Mendoza won a special election for comptroller in 2016 to serve the final two years of the late Judy Baar Topinka’s term. Mendoza earned reelection bids in 2018 <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2022/11/8/23444999/illinois-election-comptroller-treasurer-susana-mendoza-michael-frerichs-shannon-teresi-tom-demmer" target="_blank" >and 2022</a>. She is the highest-ranking Latina elected official in Illinois. Mendoza, 53, previously served as the Chicago city clerk and as a state representative, and she unsuccessfully ran for mayor of Chicago in 2019. She announced <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2025/07/16/susana-mendoza-chicago-mayor-comptroller-brandon-johnson" target="_blank" >last summer</a> she would not seek reelection as she considered her “next biggest challenge.”</p><h3><b>Who are the candidates?</b></h3><p>Three of the four candidates in the Democratic primary are state legislators: Rep. Margaret Croke of Chicago, Rep. Stephanie Kifowit of Oswego, and Sen. Karina Villa of West Chicago. The fourth is Lake County Treasurer Holly Kim. Bryan Drew, an attorney from downstate Benton, is the lone candidate for comptroller in the Republican primary. None of the candidates received an endorsement from Mendoza.</p><p>Croke and Kifowit are more moderate Democrats. Croke boasts endorsements from House Speaker Emanuel “Chris” Welch and 30 other House Democrats, while Kifowit is backed by multiple labor unions, veterans groups, a few House Democrats and many suburban elected officials.</p><p>Kim possesses a progressive vision but has earned votes in historically conservative areas of Lake County. She has endorsements from U.S. Rep. Brad Schneider, numerous local elected officials from across the state and several unions.</p><p>Villa is a progressive who has been a strong advocate for immigrants, as well as for affordable housing and lower healthcare costs. She carries endorsements from U.S. Rep. Delia Ramirez, outgoing U.S. Rep. Jesús “Chuy” García and Illinois Senate President Don Harmon.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-7d0000" name="module-7d0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Illinois 2026 primary election schedule</h3><br><b>Feb. 5</b>: Early voting and vote by mail begins<br><br><b>March 1</b>: Online voter registration ends, but voters may register in person at <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/VotingAndRegistrationSystems/EarlyVotingLocationsSearch.aspx" target="_blank" >election authority and early voting sites</a><br><br><b>March 12</b>: Deadline for online and posted applications to vote by mail; in-person requests for absentee ballots may be made through March 16<br><br><b>March 17</b>: Polls open for Primary Election Day from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.<br><br><b>March 31</b>: Deadline to return absentee ballots postmarked on or before Primary Election Day</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: What to know about the open U.S. Senate seat to replace Dick Durbin
entries.summary: <p>U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin's announcement last year not to seek a sixth term sparked a high stakes political shuffle and a contentious open race among top Illinois Democrats to replace him. </p><p></p><h3>Who are the candidates?</h3><h3></h3><p>U.S. Rep. Robin Kelly, U.S. Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi, Lt. Gov. Juliana Stratton, Steve Botsford Jr., Sean Brown, Awisi A. Bustos, Jonathan Dean, Bryan Maxwell, Kevin Ryan and Christopher Swann.</p><h3>How long is the term?</h3><p>The seat's six-year term will begin January 2027.</p><h3>So what?</h3><p>Durbin's announcement was anticipated, but it led to a seismic shift in Illinois politics, where a long roster of Democrats who had been quietly jockeying for his position were able to jump into the spotlight. Krishnamoorthi and Kelly's runs also led to open races in both the 2nd and 8th congressional districts. And Stratton's run led to Gov. JB Pritzker choosing Christian Mitchell as his lieutenant governor pick for his reelection campaign. A New York Times tally of polling in the race, dating back to June 2025, shows Krishnamoorthi, Stratton and Kelly consistently leading the race. </p><h3>What does a U.S. senator do? </h3><p>Senators take action on bills, resolutions, amendments, motions, nominations and treaties by voting. Most importantly, they can confirm U.S. presidential appointments, approve or reject treaties and can convict or exonerate impeachment cases — which could be a factor during President Donald Trump's second term. </p><h3>Why is a U.S. senator a powerful position? </h3><p>The Senate is the most powerful chamber because no bill can become law, and no office can be filled, without the support of the Senate. Six-year terms also give senators more influence on national policies — and senators often use filibusters to delay or block legislation. Senators also have the ability to oversee federal agencies and budgets — although that power appears to be more limited under the Trump administration. </p><h3>Who are the candidates? </h3><p>Robin Kelly, who lives in south suburban Matteson, has <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/05/06/rep-robin-kelly-senate-bid-dick-durbin" target="_blank" >represented the 2nd Congressional District since 2013</a> and previously served in the Illinois House. She also served as chief of staff to Illinois Treasurer Alexi Giannoulias and as Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle’s chief administrative officer. Her economic plan is aimed at affordability and calls for taxing the ultra rich, raising the minimum wage and expanding Medicare.</p><p>Raja Krishnamoorthi, who has <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/05/07/raja-krishnamoorthi-launches-senate-bid" target="_blank" >represented the 8th Congressional District since 2018</a>, announced his bid a day after Kelly. The fundraising leader called himself a “first-generation kid” who can stand up to bullies and billionaires. His economic policy includes a nationwide free lunch program, expanding the child tax credit and helping first-time homeowners get a refundable tax credit.</p><p>Juliana Stratton, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/04/23/lt-gov-juliana-stratton-candidacy-us-senate-dick-durbin-seat" target="_blank" >the first Democrat to enter the field,</a> said her path to the Senate may not be typical, “but then again, typical isn’t what we need right now.” She was quickly endorsed by Gov. JB Pritzker and Sen. Tammy Duckworth. One of Stratton's top economic priorities is to raise the federal minimum wage to $15 and she wants to expand the earned income tax credit for low and moderate-income workers. </p><p>Steve Botsford Jr. served on the legislative staff for U.S. Rep. Tony Cárdenas (D-Calif.) and later worked full-time in the finance industry. He ran for City Council in 2023 but lost to Ald. Timmy Knudsen (43rd). He says he's running because "Washington insiders keep leading the country in the wrong direction." </p><p>Sean Brown is an attorney and community organizer from the South Side. He wants universal healthcare, immigration reform, a new violence prevention and safety act and free tuition for public universities and colleges. </p><p>Awisi A. Bustos is a nonprofit executive and first-generation Ghanaian American. She previously served as the chief executive officer of the Illinois Alliance of Boys & Girls Clubs, where she oversaw a $11 million budget. She says her mission is "to restore integrity, justice, and purpose to public service."</p><p>Jonathan Dean is an activist, entrepreneur and litigator — and he calls himself "a proud survivor of childhood sexual abuse." He says he's running because Illinois needs a senator who "will shock the system into working for young people, working families, and our children’s futures and stand against fascism and for American freedom."</p><p>Bryan Maxwell is an assistant research scientist and project engineer for the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He has spent the last two years "organizing to stop sending our tax dollars to Israel for its genocide in Gaza." He believes tax dollars should be spent on local communities, "not bombing them overseas." </p><p>Kevin Ryan is a Chicago Public Schools teacher and a U.S. Marine Corps veteran. He says that Trump's return and "the Democratic Party's critical failures" made him want to run for public office: "We can no longer afford more machine politics, bowing to billionaires, or those who wait for 'their turn.'"</p><p>Christopher Swann is a deacon and nonprofit leader. Swann supports Palestinian freedom, working to end hunger and a guaranteed income for families below the poverty line. He also supports Medicare for All. </p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-560000" name="module-560000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Illinois 2026 primary election schedule</h3><br><b>Feb. 5</b>: Early voting and vote by mail begins<br><br><b>March 1</b>: Online voter registration ends, but voters may register in person at <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/VotingAndRegistrationSystems/EarlyVotingLocationsSearch.aspx" target="_blank" >election authority and early voting sites</a><br><br><b>March 12</b>: Deadline for online and posted applications to vote by mail; in-person requests for absentee ballots may be made through March 16<br><br><b>March 17</b>: Polls open for Primary Election Day from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.<br><br><b>March 31</b>: Deadline to return absentee ballots postmarked on or before Primary Election Day</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: What to know about the Democratic primary for Cook County board president
entries.summary: <p>Ald. Brendan Reilly (42nd) <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/09/10/alderman-brendan-reilly-cook-county-board-president-campaign" >faces off</a> against longtime incumbent Toni Preckwinkle in the March 17 Democratic primary for Cook County board president. Here's a closer look at the race. </p><h3><b>What does the Cook County board president do?</b></h3><p>The Cook County board president is the chief executive of one of the biggest counties in America. The president oversees the county’s jail, vast court system and large public health system that has a mission and legacy to treat patients <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2025/05/23/how-medicaid-cuts-from-congress-could-affect-every-cook-county-resident" target="_blank" ><u>no matter if they can pay</u></a>. The county employs more than 20,000 people. A big part of the job is crafting the annual <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/11/20/cook-county-board-toni-preckwinkle-10-billion-2026-budget" target="_blank" ><u>county budget</u></a>, which the 17-member Board of Commissioners must approve. The president also oversees the <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2024/04/27/palos-preserves-gets-10-million-makeover" target="_blank" ><u>Forest Preserves</u></a> of Cook County, which has more than 70,000 acres of natural areas where people can hike, fish, bike, camp and even zipline.</p><h3><b>Why is the Cook County board president a powerful position?</b></h3><p>The president controls a massive budget of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/11/20/cook-county-board-toni-preckwinkle-10-billion-2026-budget" target="_blank" ><u>around $10 billion</u></a>, together with commissioners steering money throughout Chicago and dozens of suburbs. In recent years, the county has invested in <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/cook-county/2025/04/08/cook-county-leaders-are-touting-the-success-of-their-guaranteed-income-pilot-program" target="_blank" ><u>guaranteed income</u></a> for residents with low to moderate income and erased more than $600 million <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/health-medicine/2025/06/05/cook-county-erases-nearly-665-million-in-medical-debt-for-more-than-a-half-million-residents" target="_blank" ><u>of medical debt</u></a> for more than 500,000 people. The president also must manage relationships with political leaders, from local mayors and Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker to the White House. The county health system, for example, is <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2025/05/23/how-medicaid-cuts-from-congress-could-affect-every-cook-county-resident" target="_blank" ><u>heavily dependent on dollars</u></a> from the federal government.</p><h3><b>Who is the incumbent, Toni Preckwinkle?</b></h3><h3></h3><p>Preckwinkle, who turns 79 on March 17, the day of the general primary, was a history teacher and longtime Chicago alderperson representing the South Side before she was elected county board president in 2010. She uses her <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2024/03/15/how-toni-preckwinkle-wields-her-political-power" target="_blank" ><u>political muscle and progressive values</u></a> to shape how the county spends money, with equity top of mind. Preckwinkle also is <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/politics/2024/04/22/toni-preckwinkle-is-unanimously-re-elected-head-of-the-cook-county-democratic-party" target="_blank" ><u>head of the Cook County Democratic Party</u></a>, a powerful position that can make or break candidates who want the party’s blessing and resources to run for a county seat or become a judge. She has mentored many into higher office, from her former chief of staff Kim Foxx, who became Cook County state’s attorney, to <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2025/07/04/pritzker-running-mate-christian-mitchell-chosen-one-rich-miller" target="_blank" ><u>Christian Mitchell</u></a>, who is Pritzker’s <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/illinois-governor/2025/07/01/jb-pritzker-christian-mitchell-lieutenant-governor-third-term-campaign" target="_blank" ><u>running mate</u></a>.</p><h3><b>Who is the opponent, Ald. Brendan Reilly?</b></h3><p>Reilly, 54, has represented Chicago’s downtown 42nd Ward in the City Council since 2007, when he unseated a three-decade incumbent, former <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2020/6/11/21288690/former-downtown-ald-burt-natarus-dies-council-obituary-carriages-valet-street-musicians" >Ald. Burt Natarus. </a>Reilly often votes with a bloc of the council’s more conservative alderpersons but is a self-proclaimed “independent voice” on the Council. He has focused on increased transparency around executive decision-making, most notably during his stiff opposition to the development of a Chicago casino in what he felt was a rushed and secretive process. Reilly was a close ally of former Mayor Rahm Emanuel, serving as Emanuel’s vice mayor. He served as president pro tempore under former Mayor Lori Lightfoot, though he grew increasingly critical of Lightfoot and backed her opponent, Paul Vallas, during her 2023 reelection bid. Reilly is a frequent and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/fran-spielman-show/2024/09/12/brandon-johnson-unprepared-mayor-2027-election-city-council-reilly" >harsh critic</a> of Mayor Brandon Johnson.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-6b0000" name="module-6b0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Illinois 2026 primary election schedule</h3><br><b>Feb. 5</b>: Early voting and vote by mail begins<br><br><b>March 1</b>: Online voter registration ends, but voters may register in person at <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/VotingAndRegistrationSystems/EarlyVotingLocationsSearch.aspx" target="_blank" >election authority and early voting sites</a><br><br><b>March 12</b>: Deadline for online and posted applications to vote by mail; in-person requests for absentee ballots may be made through March 16<br><br><b>March 17</b>: Polls open for Primary Election Day from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.<br><br><b>March 31</b>: Deadline to return absentee ballots postmarked on or before Primary Election Day</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: What to know about the Democratic primary race for Cook County assessor
entries.summary: <p>The Democratic primary race for Cook County assessor comes at a fraught time, when residential property tax bills are rising fastest in predominantly Black neighborhoods on the South and West sides.</p><p>It’s because the county’s tax burden is being shifted away from the economic center of the city — as large businesses and wealthy land owners appeal at higher rates and more successfully, shifting more of the burden onto low income home owners — according to a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2025/11/17/cook-county-property-taxes-analysis-treasurer-maria-pappas-downtown-south-west-sides?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=11172025%20Morning%20Edition&utm_content=11172025%20Morning%20Edition+CID_06f49f4c104db8c861653fcf9ca001a0&utm_source=cst_campaign_monitor&utm_term=Black%20neighborhoods%20are%20hit%20hardest%20with%20Cook%20County%20property%20tax%20bill%20increase%20Analysis&tpcc=cst_cm" target="_blank" ><u>Cook County treasurer’s office report last month</u></a> and a Chicago Sun-Times <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/03/07/property-taxes-loop-pandemic-christopher-berry-pat-quinn-joseph-schwieterman-joseph-ferguson-farzin-parang?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=11172025%20Morning%20Edition&utm_content=11172025%20Morning%20Edition+CID_06f49f4c104db8c861653fcf9ca001a0&utm_source=cst_campaign_monitor&utm_term=Sun-Times%20broke%20the%20news&tpcc=cst_cm" target="_blank" ><u>analysis of five years of tax bills</u></a>.</p><p>Other neighborhoods, such as Pilsen, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2022/12/30/23532836/property-taxes-increase-pilsen-residents-protest-gentrification-cook-county" target="_blank" ><u>have seen similar increases</u></a><u>.</u> </p><p>With that backdrop, the Cook County Democratic Party chose to endorse incumbent Fritz Kaegi’s challenger, Lyons Township Assessor Pat Hynes, though top Democrats are still split between property tax burden shifts to neighborhoods</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p><h3><b>What does the Cook County Assessor do?</b></h3><p>The Cook County assessor's office is in charge of appraising the county’s land parcels. It also handles tax incentives, exemptions and some appeals.</p><p>The office reassesses one third of the county every year as it plays its role in helping to establish each property’s tax burden.</p><p>Assessors serve for four year terms, and have no term limits.</p><h3><b>Why is the Cook County Assessor a powerful position?</b></h3><p>The office has a hefty influence in the property tax process.</p><p>Blunders on appraisals or exemptions can mean a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2024/11/15/senior-freeze-property-tax-fritz-kaegi-cook-county-assessor" target="_blank" ><u>difference of thousands of dollars</u></a> on a tax bill — revenue</u></a> — though several employees have also been <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/05/27/ex-cook-county-assessors-employee-gets-probation-after-admitting-to-bribery-scheme-helping-feds" target="_blank" ><u>charged with taking probation after admitting to bribery scheme, helping feds</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p><h3><b>Who is the incumbent ?</b></h3><p>Fritz Kaegi, of Oak Park, is running for this third term as assessor, first winning in 2018 and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2022/6/28/23187336/fritz-kaegi-kari-steele-cook-county-assessor-democratic-primary-george-cardenas-george-tammy-wendt" >again in 2022</a>.</p><p>He first ran as a reformist at a time when the office came under fire under former assessor Joe Berrios — whose assessment methods often favored wealthier property owners and allowed them to pay less in property taxes than those in low-income and minority communities. One of Kaegi's first moves was adopting a <a class="Link" href="https://prodassets.cookcountyassessoril.gov/s3fs-public/page_comm/ExecutiveOrder.pdf" target="_blank" ><u>new code of ethics</u></a> for the office.</p><p>Prior to his time in office, Kaegi was a mutual fund portfolio manager and analyst for 20 years.</p><h3><b>Who is the opponent? </b></h3><p>Pat Hynes, a Western Springs resident, is near the end of his first term as Lyons Township assessor after 23 years working in the Cook County Assessor’s office as a residential field inspector.</p><p>Hynes sits on the Cook County Assessors Association Board and is a firefighter/EMT with the Western Springs Fire Department. He is also the nephew of Thomas Hynes, a former five-term Cook County assessor and past Illinois Senate president. </p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-2c0000" name="module-2c0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Illinois 2026 primary election schedule</h3><br><b>Feb. 5</b>: Early voting and vote by mail begins<br><br><b>March 1</b>: Online voter registration ends, but voters may register in person at <a class="Link" href="https://www.elections.il.gov/VotingAndRegistrationSystems/EarlyVotingLocationsSearch.aspx" target="_blank" >election authority and early voting sites</a><br><br><b>March 12</b>: Deadline for online and posted applications to vote by mail; in-person requests for absentee ballots may be made through March 16<br><br><b>March 17</b>: Polls open for Primary Election Day from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m.<br><br><b>March 31</b>: Deadline to return absentee ballots postmarked on or before Primary Election Day</div> </div><p></p><p></p><p></p><p></p><p></p>

entries.title: Previewing and predicting this weekend's top high school basketball games
entries.summary: <p>As the calendar turns to February and win totals climb into the 20s for teams, the realization hits that sectional seeding time is right around the corner. This weekend is another opportunity to enhance the profile in the final couple of weeks before coaches submit their seeds.</p><p>Here are previews and picks for six games to keep an eye on.</p><p><i>Last week’s record: 5-2</i></p><p><i>Season record: 24-9</i></p><h3>No. 12 Mount Carmel (16-8) at No. 15 St. Ignatius (22-4), Friday</h3><h3></h3><p>The teeth of the schedule has hit a young Mount Carmel team hard. The Caravan have fallen short in three recent losses to ranked teams (DePaul, Homewood-Flossmoor and Kankakee), so a significant win would surely come in handy with seeding time coming.</p><p>Another tough road game against a ranked team in the Catholic League awaits.</p><p>Ignatius is a team that has beaten top-ranked Benet — the only team to do so — but also lost to Joliet Catholic. But despite that high and low, St. Ignatius has been a relatively consistent team all season, just as the record would indicate.</p><p>In a game with plenty of young talent on display, the home floor and the fact the best, most impactful player is St. Ignatius senior Chris Bolte gives coach Matt Monroe’s team the edge.</p><p><i>The pick: St. Ignatius 63, Mount Carmel 56</i></p><h3>No. 5 Warren (22-2) at No. 24 Stevenson (17-7), Friday</h3><h3></h3><p>Warren’s lone two losses on the season have come to No. 1 Benet and No. 3 Curie.</p><p>Stevenson beat Waukegan last week and climbed into the back end of the Super 25 rankings. But then lost to Lake Forest earlier this week. The Patriots are trying to avoid this being the high water mark of the season. But upsetting Jaxson Davis and Company will be a monumental task.</p><p>This one might look better on paper than what transpires Friday night.</p><p><i>The pick: Warren 63, Stevenson 50</i></p><h3>Rich (13-11) at No. 4 Kankakee (20-1), Friday</h3><h3></h3><p>With star Lincoln Williams leading the way, Kankakee is running away with things in the Southland Conference. Williams has played with a sense of urgency and responded as a stat-sheet-stuffing senior star with 26 points, six rebounds and over two assists and steals a game.</p><p>When you add EJ Hazelett (16 ppg, 8 rpg), who has signed with Indiana State, it’s a pick-your-poison situation when facing the Kays.</p><p>The overall record and inconsistency from Rich are noticeable. But this one jumps out due to the return this week of Rich’s top player, senior guard Jameson Coulter, who poured in 25 points in three quarters in his debut — a nice win over Bloom earlier this week.</p><p><i>The pick: Kankakee 70, Rich 62</i></p><h3>No. 3 Curie (20-1) vs. No. 14 Glenbard East (23-3) at Kankakee, Saturday</h3><p>The biggest — at the very least the most intriguing — game of the weekend highlights the Chops Billinger Shootout at Kankakee. These are some pretty glitzy records these two have compiled.</p><p>Curie is in the midst of what it hopes is a city title run but can’t look past a ranked and experienced Glenbard East team.</p><p>Glenbard East, meanwhile, desperately needs to play a high-quality opponent to test its mettle. This is the first ranked opponent the Rams have faced since losing to St. Ignatius in late December and are just 1-2 against ranked teams this season.</p><p>Maybe the Rams were looking ahead to playing the No. 3 ranked team when it was stunned Tuesday night by Riverside-Brookfield, dropping them into a tie for first in the Upstate Eight East.</p><p>The star attraction is in the backcourt. A pair of senior guards, Glenbard East’s Michael Nee and Curie’s Justin Oliver, have led the way for these two and have done so in impressive fashion.</p><p><i>The pick: Curie 65, Glenbard East 55</i></p><h3>No. 21 New Trier (19-6) at No. 16 Fremd (20-2), Saturday</h3><h3></h3><p>New Trier has found its way since losing star Christopher Kirkpatrick, whose injury status still remains up in the air. But after dropping three straight mid-January games without Kirkpatrick, coach Scott Fricke’s team has now won six in a row.</p><p>Danny Houlihan continues to step up. The senior shooting guard is averaging 16 points a game. Then there has been a whole lot of balance and support from four players – Denym Wallace, Elton Jaegerskog, Matthew Logue and Max Vogel — who all are sharing the ball and averaging between 8-9 points a game.</p><p>Fremd has bounced back nicely since an upset loss to Lakes two weeks ago, including an emotional overtime win over Palatine last weekend.</p><p>A bounce-back like that is to be expected with a trio of three veteran seniors like Jordan Williams, Tommy Moffett and Rafael Pinto. Those three bring size, length, versatility and remarkably consistent play and production.</p><p>The 6-6 Williams, an Illinois State recruit, is putting up 18 points, six rebounds and 2.5 assists, while the 6-5 versatile Moffett adds 12.5 points, nearly seven rebounds and over three assists a game. Pinto, a 6-5 scoring wing, averages 15.5 points a game.</p><p>This could be a barnburner.</p><p><i>The pick: New Trier 52, Fremd 50</i></p><h3>No. 17 Palatine (21-4) at Cary-Grove (22-3), Saturday</h3><h3></h3><p>It’s been quite a run for surprising Cary-Grove, a team that boasts strong senior leadership and balance. The Trojans have some size — 6-7 senior Adam Bauer leads the Trojans with 16 points and eight rebounds a game — and a solid senior backcourt with 6-2 point guard AJ Berndt (13 ppg, 3 apg) and 6-2 Dylan Dumele, a perimeter shooting threat who averages 12 points a game.</p><p>Fresh off what will be a fight for first in the Fox Valley Conference against Burlington Central on Friday night, the battle with Palatine offers a different opportunity for this team. It’s a terrific late-season measuring stick against a ranked foe. Can Cary-Grove rise to the occasion?</p><p>Palatine is enjoying quite the regular season as well. The 21 wins is impressive, but the four losses came to teams with a combined record of 81-19. Plus, those four losses were by a combined 13 points and include two overtime defeats. Those defeats hardly warrant a plummet in the rankings.</p><p>Tony Balanganayi has grabbed a lot of the attention as he’s emerged as a dominating big man for the Pirates. But seniors Darrin Dick and the athletic Abram Williams, along with junior Brady May, complement Balanganayi well.</p><p><i>The pick: Palatine 55, Cary-Grove 46</i></p>

entries.title: Bulls coach Billy Donovan said he has no plans to walk away from a rebuild
entries.summary: <p>TORONTO — The narrative surrounding <b>Billy Donovan’s</b> mutual departure from Oklahoma City was that the coach didn’t want to go through a rebuild following the 2019-20 season.</p><p>That wasn’t entirely true.</p><p>If he was going to go through a rebuild, he just wanted to be in the communication loop a bit more.</p><p>So of course it was brought up again on Thursday, as the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls" >Bulls</a> are in full rebuild mode after making a flurry of trades. That’s why Donovan was asked about the idea of riding this out.</p><p>“Yeah, the part about the OKC thing, even when I kind of came [to the Bulls] it was a rebuild in terms of we had a lot of young guys, there were some decisions that were going to be made,” Donovan said. “To be honest with you, most of my time in college was to rebuild teams and rosters. We have to sit down as an organization quite honestly, myself, ownership and front office, and find the direction, the clarity, of, again, the roster is kind of flipped, right?</p><p>“I’ve talked to you guys about what’s important to me is the mentality, the competitiveness, that kind of stuff, and things can happen quickly too. Look at what Detroit was able to do. They were really bad for a while and they took off and have done really well.</p><p>“You look at a team like Boston, where they shed a bunch of salary cap and people thought they weren’t going to be any good and now they’re second in the East, so things can happen pretty quickly.”</p><p>Maybe, but this latest Bulls rebuild doesn’t feel quick.</p><p>Some of the new pieces were in the mix for the 123-107 loss to the Raptors on Thursday, as <b>Anfernee Simons, Jaden Ivey</b> and <b>Guerschon Yabusele</b> each made their Bulls debut. <b>Rob Dillingham </b>and <b>Collin Sexton</b> are expected to make their debuts Saturday.</p><p>Yabusele finished with 15 points and 11 rebounds, Simons had 22 points on six threes, and Ivey had 13 points.</p><p>What the trio also had in common was being suprised by how fast the Bulls play, and it wasn’t even full speed in Donovan’s eyes.</p><p>“Oh yeah, super tough,” Simons said of the adjustment. “I was pretty tired and [Donovan] was telling us to play even faster. Got a few ways to go to get in shape and play that way but everyone is bought into playing that way. All the new guys that aren’t used to it just got to continue to take each and every game to get in condition.”</p><h3><b>Money man</b></h3><p>The initial outside feeling was Simons and Sexton — both unrestricted free agents at the end of the season — would be allowed to walk come July 1, but executive <b>Arturas Karnisovas</b> said that wasn’t necessarily the case.</p><p>If one or both impress during the final few months of the season, Karnisovas has no problem re-upping them to stay put.</p><p>“That [financial flexibility] gives us real options whether that’s free agency, trades, the draft or continue an investment in development,” Karnisovas said. “Flexibility that allows us to be patient but decisive when the right opportunity presents itself.”</p><h3><b>Training room</b></h3><p><b>Josh Giddey</b> missed his fifth game since the hamstring tightness resurfaced, but don’t expect a quick return for the point guard, especially if he’s not 100%.</p><p>Not only do the Bulls view winning as a lower priority, but they also want to see as much as they can of all the new guards who were added. The best way to do that is with playing time.</p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-hide-descriptions="true" data-show-loadmore="true" ><a class="AnchorLink" id="list-8f0005" name="list-8f0005"></a><div class="PageList-header" > <div class="PageList-header-title-wrap" > <div class="PageList-header-title"> <a class="" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls" target="{borderColor=#dfdfdf, pagination=[{body=[Next Page], href=?p=2, _template=/link/Link.hbs, contentId=null, pianoSectionSlug=null, target=null}], pageNumber=1, inverseColors=false, footerBgColor=#000000, bodyFont=font-3, showListNumbers=false, imagePositionHorizontal=null, rteBodyFont=font-3, headerBottomBorderColor=#111010, subTitle=null, stickyHeader=true, listTitleColor=#000000, tableCellBorderColor=#ccd1d5, relatedListFont=font-1, hideAuthors=true, tertiaryTextColor=#6c6c6c, buttonHoverTextColor=#ffffff, tableFont=font-1, carouselAutoPlay=false, items=[{type=Image, media=[{ampLink=null, _styledTemplate=null, _template=/image/Image.hbs, image={src=https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/45/24/aac6b8da48d4a7f999f29e0a773a/bulls-media-day-basketball.jpg, width=5329, height=3553}, alt=Bulls Media Day Basketball, narrowImage={src=https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/45/24/aac6b8da48d4a7f999f29e0a773a/bulls-media-day-basketball.jpg, width=5329, height=3553}}], title=Don't call it a 'rebuild,' as Bulls' Arturas Karnisovas changes roster, _styledTemplate=null, anchorId=promo-f40000, imageAlignment=null, isFeatured=false, categoryUrl=https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls, target=null, primaryMediaType=null, wordCount=628, url=https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls/2026/02/05/bulls-arturas-karnisovas-changes-roster, ampLink=null, description=[{items=[Karnisovas made seven trades leading up to the Thursday deadline, including parting ways withCoby White, Ayo Dosunmu, Nikola Vucevic, and Kevin Huerter. entries.title: NFL Honors: Bears' Joe Thuney wins Protector award; Mike Vrabel beats Ben Johnson for Coach of the Year
entries.summary: <p>SAN FRANCISCO — <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> coach Ben Johnson lost out to the Patriots’ Mike Vrabel for Coach of the Year at the NFL Honors on Thursday, but they still picked up a trophy as left guard <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/05/bears-players-in-san-francisco-for-super-bowl-lx-sick-about-being-so-close-yet-so-far-from-lombardi-trophy" >Joe Thuney</a> won the league’s inaugural Protector of the Year for the top offensive lineman.</p><p>Thuney, always averse to attention, joked, “It’s kind of ironic talking about an award for unsung heroes.”</p><p>He earned his third consecutive All-Pro and fourth consecutive Pro Bowl selection this season after the Bears acquired him in a trade with the Chiefs. He was instrumental in their overhaul of the offensive line, coming in with center Drew Dalman and right guard Jonah Jackson, and even filled in at left tackle in the playoffs when Ozzy Trapilo suffered a knee injury.</p><p>The group helped quarterback Caleb Williams cut his sacks from a league-high 68 as a rookie to just 24 this season.</p><p>Thuney already had a decorated career with the Patriots and Chiefs, winning two Super Bowls with each before coming to the Bears. This was a new challenge, though, in that they were counting on him to lead a turnaround.</p><p>“I just wanted to show the guys in the locker room what I’ve learned through my years and just perform well for the guy next to me,” Thuney said. “The offensive line in Chicago really grew close. I love those guys.</p><p>“It was surreal being at Soldier Field and feeling the fans and hearing it and seeing videos of families’ reactions after the games and they’re crying together and laughing and cheering. The city hasn’t felt that in a long time, so it was special.”</p><p>Johnson, meanwhile, had a strong candidacy by steering the Bears from 5-12 last season to 11-6 and their first playoff win in 15 years. Vrabel, though, pulled off an even more impressive flip by taking the 4-12 Patriots to a 14-3 record. All voting was done at the end of the regular season.</p><p>Johnson finished fourth in the voting behind Vrabel (302 points, 19 first-place votes), the Jaguars' Liam Coen (239 points, 16 first-place votes) and the Seahawks' Mike Macdonald (191 points, eight first-place votes). Johnson finished with 145 points, receiving one first-place vote, just ahead of the 49ers' Kyle Shanahan with 140 points and six first-place votes.</p><p>Williams and wide receiver DJ Moore also were honored for the Moment of the Year for Williams’ 46-yard touchdown pass to Moore to beat the Packers in overtime in December.</p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module entries.title: Dozens of Chicago suburbs have shifted to majority nonwhite
entries.summary: <p>In north suburban Skokie, a cluster of low-slung strip malls along Dempster Street is a microcosm of the town’s changing population.</p><p></p><p>A grocery store selling Cameroonian and Nigerian produce, opened a year and a half ago, stands across the street from a Chinese restaurant serving a regional street food speciality.</p><p></p><p>“We have a diverse culture here,” said Mado Mbasso, owner of Mado’s African Market, a small grocery store that caters to a growing West African diaspora in the northwest suburbs. “There are Chinese people. My next door [neighbor], I think they are Jewish, the other ones are Europeans.”</p><p></p><p>The town’s diversity is partially why Vincent Yang, owner of Monkey King Jianbing, brought his business to Skokie. “There are lots of people from different countries here in Skokie who can try <i>jianbing</i>, which is famous in China but relatively new in America,” Yang said in Mandarin.</p><p></p><p>Just a parking lot away sits an old-school kosher diner that has been run by the same family for the past 50 years. Skokie is a “melting pot,” said Adam Freed, the new owner of the longtime kosher eatery, Ken’s Diner & Grill.</p><p></p><p>A generation ago, the suburb was more than 90% white. The latest census figures show the racial and ethnic breakdown of the village’s roughly 66,000 residents is now 48% white, 25% Asian, 11% Latino and 10% Black.</p><p></p><p>Skokie is one of more than thirty Chicago-area suburbs that have shifted from majority-white communities to majority non-white ones in the past two decades, according to a WBEZ analysis of demographic data for nearly 300 suburbs in Cook County and the five collar counties from 2005 to 2024.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Mado Mbasso, the owner of Mado’s African market located at 3522 Dempster St. in Skokie, leans against a shelf inside her African grocery story.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere / Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The figures come from the latest release of the U.S. Census Bureau’s American Community Survey five-year estimates, which include the most updated data for communities with less than 20,000 residents.</p><p></p><p>Suburban communities across the country have been diversifying for decades, but in recent years, the number of Chicago-area suburbs whose demographics have flipped has accelerated.</p><p></p><p>Between 2015 and 2024, 18 suburbs flipped from majority-white to majority non-white, up from 12 during the prior 10-year period spanning 2005 through 2014.</p><p></p><p>Many suburbs today are no longer the white, middle-class enclaves of the mid-20th century, said Willow Lung, an associate professor of urban studies and planning and director of the Small Business Anti-Displacement Network at the University of Maryland.</p><p></p><p>Demographic changes began after laws and practices prohibiting racial and ethnic integration in the suburbs were dismantled, like redlining and restrictions on selling homes to nonwhite residents. More recently, increased job opportunities in the suburbs and a growing cost of living in the cities have also pushed residents further out.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-010000" name="html-embed-module-010000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-map" data-src="visualisation/27516670"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27516670/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="map visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>“Suburbs have not only become more racially diverse, they’ve also become more economically diverse, and they have become much more the centers of new immigration,” Lung said.</p><p></p><p>The median incomes of Chicago-area suburbs range from about $30,000 to more than $250,000, and about 19% of suburban residents in Cook and surrounding counties were born outside of the United States, according to WBEZ’s analysis.</p><p></p><p>The suburbs are also where the region’s nonwhite population is growing the most compared to the city of Chicago.</p><p></p><p>In the last 20 years, gains in the suburban Latino population far outpaced any increases in the city. The number of Black residents in the suburbs grew while Chicago’s Black population continued to decline. Meanwhile, the Asian population grew slightly faster in Chicago than the suburbs.</p><p></p><p>Overall, an increase of more than 600,000 nonwhite suburban residents over the last two decades completely offset the region’s loss of white suburban residents.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" toes the number of Black students”</h3><p></p><p>Many south suburban communities have been majority-Black for several decades, but there are three that flipped relatively recently from majority-white to majority-Black. Flossmoor, which is now 60% Black, 30% white and 5% Latino, is one of them.</p><p></p><p>Gerald Pauling has seen the demographic shifts firsthand. His family moved to south suburban Flossmoor from the Detroit area in 1979 when he was in junior high.</p><p></p><p>“When I was at Homewood-Flossmoor High School, it was clearly 99% white,” Pauling said. “I could count on my hands and toes the number of Black students that I attended high school with.”</p><p></p><p>Pauling, who now serves as the president of the Homewood-Flossmoor Board of Education, said families move to Flossmoor for the quality of schools, the diversity of the town and the town’s leadership and also that there are “successful people of color in the area.”</p><p></p><p>Flossmoor has a median household income of $133,663, making it the highest-income majority-Black suburb in the Chicago area.</p><p></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> multiple municipalities”</h3><p></p><p>In the southwest suburbs, many places have seen significant increases in their Latino populations in the last two decades.</p><p></p><p>“The availability of the job market is, I think, what primarily has driven that growth,” said Joliet Township Supervisor Cesar Guerrero, who was born and raised in Joliet and lives on the town’s east side, a predominantly Mexican-American neighborhood.</p><p></p><p>Joliet is one of the largest suburbs to have seen its demographics flip from majority-white to majority-nonwhite. It’s now 44% white, 34% Latino and 16% Black.</p><p></p><p>The warehousing and logistics industries in southwest suburbs like Joliet, Romeoville and Bolingbrook have boomed in recent years because of their locations next to multiple interstates.</p><p></p><p>“If you were to ask residents of Joliet, either they themselves or somebody immediately related to them has or is working in a warehouse,” said Guerrero.</p><p></p><p>While many suburbs have diversified at a rapid clip, the social services infrastructure needed to meet new residents’ needs has yet to catch up in some places, said José Eduardo Vera, the executive director of the Southwest Suburban Immigrant Project based in Bolingbrook.</p><p></p><p>Vera said local government services often aren’t translated into the languages some residents speak, which makes it hard for many immigrants to get help with accessing municipal services or healthcare in their communities. His nonprofit organization has been trying to fill some of those gaps, but it’s been challenging with limited resources, he said.</p><p></p><p>During last fall’s enhanced immigration enforcement, a rapid response volunteer program that the nonprofit helped convene was stretched thin trying to cover all of Will County and parts of DuPage County.</p><p></p><p>“In the city, for example, I know there's many [rapid response] groups that are neighborhood-based. Here in the suburbs, we're covering multiple municipalities,” Vera said.</p><p></p><p>As a result, some changes are piecemeal. Over the past year, Vera’s group has advocated for local governments to pass ordinances prohibiting federal immigration enforcement from taking place on city property.</p><p></p><p>“It is difficult entries.title: Illinois Hispanic Chamber of Commerce initiative aims to help Latino small businesses
entries.summary: <p>The Illinois Hispanic Chamber of Commerce on Thursday launched an initiative to help small businesses and neighborhoods in the Chicago area recover from the effects of raids by federal immigration agents.</p><p>Its <a class="Link" href="https://ihccbusiness.net/resilientcommunitiesinitiative/" target="_blank" ><u>Resilient Communities Initiative</u></a> offers businesses grants of $1,500 to $5,000; ‘shop local’ campaigns to boost business in affected neighborhoods; and resources such as webinars for entrepreneurs. IHCC’s small business advisers are also offering support to owners and employees.</p><p>“The terrible disruption to the personal lives and small businesses in our communities began in 2025 and continues into 2026,” Jaime di Paulo, CEO of the Illinois Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, said in a news release. “We have joined the many voices across our city and region calling for an end to unfair enforcement actions and disruption of our immigrant communities.”</p><p>IHCC Foundation’s grants aim to help affected businesses cover immediate expenses. First donations will be awarded the week of March 2. Anyone can donate to the <a class="Link" href="https://ihccbusiness.net/resilientcommunitiesinitiative/microgrant/" target="_blank" ><u>grants fund</u></a>.</p><p>IHCC’s ‘shop local’ campaign aims to bring people to affected neighborhoods through in-person events and online campaigns. The <a class="Link" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/resilient-communities-shop-local-neighborhood-event-brighton-park-tickets-1982040160475?aff=oddtdtcreator" target="_blank" ><u>first event</u></a> will be Feb. 11 in Brighton Park on S. Archer Avenue. It includes a guided neighborhood tour and lunch reservations at D' Nuez Restaurant.</p><p>The initiative’s <a class="Link" href="https://ihccbusiness.net/tools-to-protect-your-business/" target="_blank" ><u>resource page</u></a> offers an upcoming <a class="Link" href="https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_AerdnOFYSbCrbCqJKNu1RA#/registration" target="_blank" ><u>Know Your Rights Webinar</u></a>. The website also features legal, business and financial tools to support small business owners.</p><p>At IHCC’s annual <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/money/2025/10/09/business-community-leaders-support-latino-il-hispanic-chamber-commerce-conference" target="_blank" ><u>conference</u></a> last October, di Paulo said U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids in Chicago stoked fear and stifled economic opportunities.</p><p>He told the Sun-Times, “From IHCC’s perspective, conditions for Latino communities and Latino-owned businesses have worsened since October, as ongoing fear and enforcement continue to reduce foot traffic, sales and community engagement. Many businesses are facing depressed revenue and financial uncertainty.”</p><p> Latino neighborhoods like Little Village, Belmont Cragin and parts of the Southwest Side, are beginning to feel like “ghost towns,” he said.</p><p>He added, “Street vendors and small Latino-owned businesses, which are essential to the cultural and economic life of these communities, have seen sharp declines in income, with some stopping work entirely due to fear of enforcement.”</p><p>Fewer customers create ripple effects that hurt suppliers and distributors.</p><p> "Restaurants, cultural and retail businesses and the construction industry are also being hit hard — which is why IHCC and other community organizations must stay diligent in supporting and advocating for these businesses,” di Paulo said.</p><p>In <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/money/2025/10/09/business-community-leaders-support-latino-il-hispanic-chamber-commerce-conference" target="_blank" ><u>Illinois</u></a>, the gross domestic product of Latinos exceeds $100 billion, according to the University of California Los Angeles Center for the Study of Latino Health and Culture.</p><p>"Latino-owned businesses are essential to Illinois’ economy, creating jobs and strengthening neighborhoods,” di Paulo said. “Ensuring Latino enterprises are fully included in economic development is key to long-term growth across the state.”</p><p>ICE has had a broader impact on Chicago’s economy. At a press conference last November, more than 30 business and civic leaders denounced the federal government’s deportation campaign.</p><p>ICE raids have “scared people away from restaurants, cultural events, retail corridors and our Downtown — the heart of Chicago’s economic engine,” said Jack Lavin, CEO of the Chicagoland Chamber of Commerce, at the event. “The economic repercussions of ICE’s continued onslaught, if left unchecked, will be significant.”<br></p>

entries.title: Don't call it a 'rebuild,' as Bulls' Arturas Karnisovas changes roster
entries.summary: <p>TORONTO — Arturas Karnisovas has a history of rarely winning the news conference, so why start now?</p><p>But there the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls" >Bulls’</a> executive vice president of basketball operations was on Thursday, hours after the trade deadline came and went, trying to justify a rebuild that he won’t call a rebuild — it’s a “stage” in Karnisovas talk — and doing so a year later than it should have happened.</p><p>A “B” for effort in the presser, and an “F” for execution.</p><p>“The play-in is not our goal. A championship is,” Karnisovas said. “We know where we are in the standings and we are not satisfied with being in the middle as an organization or for our fans. At the same time, we are committed to building the right way without skipping steps. This process takes time, but we already made a meaningful shift in how we approach roster building and development."</p><p>“It’s my responsibility to make this better and move this organization into something sustainable at the highest level.”</p><p>That may be the most truthful thing Karnisovas said, because it has been his responsibility for six-plus seasons and he has failed miserably. Now he wants more time and patience for a teardown that should have started taking place last year at this time with a loaded 2025 draft class.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls/2026/02/05/bulls-continue-demolition-trading-ayo-dosunmu-and-others" >Bulls continue demolition of roster, trade Ayo Dosunmu and others</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls/2026/02/03/bulls-continue-changing-guard-room-acquiring-jaden-ivey-from-detroit" >Bulls deal Nikola Vucevic to Celtics, acquire Jaden Ivey in trade with Pistons</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls/2026/02/04/bulls-continue-overhaul-trading-coby-white-to-charlotte" >Bulls continue overhaul, trade Coby White to Hornets — and they’re not done</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>That’s why he was asked if he regretted not jump-starting it last February.</p><p>“I do not,” he replied. “We were at that stage as well. We continued evaluating our young guys, Josh [Giddey], it was Matas [Buzelis’] first year, so right now is good timing and we addressed it.”</p><p>They addressed something, that was for sure.</p><p>After moving mainstays Kevin Huerter, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls/2026/02/03/bulls-continue-changing-guard-room-acquiring-jaden-ivey-from-detroit" >Nikola Vucevic</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls/2026/02/04/bulls-continue-overhaul-trading-coby-white-to-charlotte" >Coby White</a> in the 24 hours leading into the deadline, the demolition continued as hometown kid <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bulls/2026/02/05/bulls-continue-demolition-trading-ayo-dosunmu-and-others" >Ayo Dosunmu</a> was sent to Minnesota with Julian Phillips a few hours after Dalen Terry was on the move to New York and then New Orleans for forward Guerschon Yabusele.</p><p>More of a bookkeeping move with Terry? Absolutely, considering he was a free agent this summer and the Bulls had no interest in re-signing him, and Yabusele agreed to lose his player option for next season. But it was also a reminder of the failures of the front office, considering Terry was a former first-round pick (18th overall in the 2022 draft) that never turned into what they wanted from the 6-6 guard. Center Walker Kessler was picked after Terry at No. 22 and could be a target for the Bulls this summer as a restricted free agent.</p><p>As for Dosunmu, he had turned into a really solid two-way player since being selected in the second round out of Illinois but was also an expiring contract. In return for Dosunmu and Phillips, the Bulls landed former No. 8 overall pick Rob Dillingham, along with forward Leonard Miller and four second-round picks. That was the other head-scratcher, considering just last week Karnisovas reiterated his disdain for second-round picks through the years.</p><p>When reminded of that he said, “Second round-picks are now currency in our industry and you cannot operate and acquire players, trade players, and we addressed it during the trade deadline. Hopefully they are going to contribute during the draft, during free agency and trying to build this team.”</p><p>It won’t be for the lack of adding second-round draft capital as he acquired nine picks in the last week and has 14 total.</p><p>So what was left after the carnage?</p><p>Patrick Williams is the longest-tenured Bull, Dillingham, Jaden Ivey, Anfernee Simons and Yabusele are on tryouts for the remainder of the season, the Reinsdorfs back the play, according to Karnisovas, and Bulls fans are left being asked to remain patient.</p><p>“Being in the middle is what we don’t want to do,” Karnisovas said. “We’ve seen that the last four years and we want to change that.”</p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" entries.title: Man found fatally shot in South Deering
entries.summary: <p>A man was fatally shot in South Deering Thursday afternoon, according to Chicago police.</p><p>Kenneth Davis, 29, was found shot in the face and shoulder inside a residence in the 9900 South Paxton Avenue at 3:31 p.m., police and the Cook County medical examiner's office said.</p><p>No one is in custody and no further information was released as of Thursday night. </p>
